name.description: Clyde Orgeron, b. 1947, is a Valentine, Louisiana native, the son of Augustin Fortunate Orgeron and Nola Barrilleaux Orgeron, who were farmers. After graduating from public high school in 1966, he worked for Freeport Sulphur Company in Port Sulphur, Louisiana, and was then transferred to a rig off of Grand Isle, Louisiana. He studied electrical engineering through home correspondence, and was transferred to the electrical and instrumentation department; he stayed with Freeport Sulphur fourteen years, until the company closed. He took a position with the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port. Orgeron married in 1968; he and his wife had two children. He is a practicing Catholic. In his retirement he lives in Cut Off, Louisiana, and Magnolia, Mississippi.

mods.abstract: "Orgeron discusses his childhood, growing up on a farm in Valentine, Louisiana. He recounts his early career at the Freeport Sulphur Company, which eventually moved him from Port Sulphur, Louisiana, to a 7/7 schedule on an offshore rig closer to Bayou Lafourche. He took correspondence courses and advanced in the company; during his time on land he and his wife were busy building a new home and starting a family. Orgeron discusses how he came to work for the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port [LOOP]. He shares his religious beliefs; as a practicing Catholic he goes to church every Sunday and is involved in religious service groups. He discusses life on the bayou, both in regards to flooding, how things were when he was a boy, and what has changed. Orgeron sings the Cajun song ""Allons Danser Colinda"" and discusses his recent trip to Nova Scotia and his connection with the people there."
